title: dialog-journal
dialog-journal
text:
Developer Guide
If you are new to using nbdev here are some useful pointers to get you started.

Install dialog_journal in Development mode
# make sure dialog_journal package is installed in development mode
$ pip install -e .

# make changes under nbs/ directory
# ...

# compile to have changes apply to dialog_journal
$ nbdev_prepare

title: dialog-journal
text:
Usage

Installation
Install latest from the GitHub repository:
$ pip install git+https://github.com/lisa/dialog-journal.git
or from conda
$ conda install -c lisa dialog_journal
or from pypi
$ pip install dialog_journal


Documentation
Documentation can be found hosted on this GitHub repository‚Äôs pages. Additionally you can find package manager specific guidelines on conda and pypi respectively.

title: dialog-journal
text:
How to use
Fill me in please! Don‚Äôt forget code examples:

1+1

2

title: core
Nbdev Setup Dialog
text:
I‚Äôd like to set up an instance of nbdev as a journaling framework in solveit where I can journal about knowledge that I‚Äôve gained through dialog engineering or via a synthesis of reading, thinking, and coding. I would like a date-based organization for primary navigational structure, but also want separate section of dialogues that I incorporate from solveit within this journal. I‚Äôd also like to make use of tags both in code cells and documentation. For example, I‚Äôd like to be able to tag someone else‚Äôs dialog that I‚Äôd like to re-visit, tag ideas, and tag fragments of knowledge that seem useful.
nbdev and quarto are installed in solveit per investigation in this dialog https://sparkling-sunset-rushes-5idg2w.solve.it.com/dialog_?name=nbdev_environment. I‚Äôm using this same instance to set up nvdev and know that I can initialize via nbdev_new. Is this a good place to start?


Yes, nbdev_new is a good starting point! It will create the basic structure for an nbdev project. However, before we run it, let‚Äôs think about a few things to customize it for your journaling needs:

Project name: What would you like to call your journal project? (e.g., ‚Äúknowledge-journal‚Äù, ‚Äúdialog-journal‚Äù, etc.)
Structure considerations: The default nbdev setup is designed for Python libraries, but we can adapt it. You mentioned wanting:

Date-based organization for primary navigation
A separate section for dialog entries
Tag support throughout


After we initialize with nbdev_new, we‚Äôll need to customize the structure and settings to support these features.
Should we start by running nbdev_new with a project name you choose, and then we can explore how to adapt the structure for your journaling workflow?
Given nb_dev is interactive, can I install from within this notebook? Will I be able to respond properly to input?



Good question! Yes, you can run nbdev_new from within a code cell in solveit, but there‚Äôs a catch with the interactive prompts.
nbdev_new will ask you questions interactively (like project name, author, etc.), and while it will technically work in a notebook cell, responding to the prompts can be tricky in this environment.
You have a couple of options:

Use command-line flags to pass all the info at once (non-interactive mode)
Try the interactive mode and see if it works smoothly in solveit

Would you like to try option 1 (providing all parameters upfront), or would you prefer to experiment with the interactive mode first to see how it behaves?
If I try the interactive mode and something goes wrong‚Ä¶ can we back out and go to the first option?



Absolutely! If the interactive mode doesn‚Äôt work well, you can just interrupt it (or let it fail), and we can switch to using the command-line flags instead. Nothing will break permanently.
The worst case is that it creates a partially configured project, which we can either delete or just run nbdev_new again with flags to overwrite it.
So yes, it‚Äôs safe to experiment. Would you like to try the interactive mode first?
I‚Äôve run set up - how shall we proceed?



Great! Now let‚Äôs see what nbdev_new created for you. Could you run:
!ls -la
This will show us the directory structure that was set up. Once we see what‚Äôs there, we can discuss how to adapt it for your journaling needs (date-based organization, dialog sections, and tagging).
What does the output show?

!ls -la

total 192
drwxrwsr-x 12 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 22:05 .
drwxr-xr-x  1 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 14:25 ..
-rw-------  1 solveit solveit   394 Nov 29 17:34 .bash_history
drwxrwsr-x  8 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 17:15 .cache
drwxrwsr-x  3 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 17:03 .config
drwxrwsr-x  8 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 17:13 .git
drwxrwxr-x  3 solveit solveit  4096 Sep  1  2024 .github
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit   109 Nov 29 14:50 .gitignore
drwxr-sr-x  3 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 14:30 .ipython
drwxrwsr-x  4 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 14:45 .local
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit     5 Nov 29 14:50 .python-version
drwxrwsr-x  5 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 14:51 .venv
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit 11337 Sep  1  2024 LICENSE
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit   111 Sep  1  2024 MANIFEST.in
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit  1361 Nov 29 17:15 README.md
drwxrwsr-x  4 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 17:15 _proc
drwxrwsr-x  2 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 17:15 dialog_journal
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit    82 Nov 29 14:50 main.py
-rw-------  1 solveit solveit 35432 Nov 29 17:17 nbdev_environment.ipynb
-rw-------  1 solveit solveit 10077 Nov 29 22:05 nbdev_setup.ipynb
drwxrwsr-x  4 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 17:28 nbs
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit   176 Nov 29 17:15 pyproject.toml
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit  1025 Nov 29 17:15 settings.ini
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit  2891 Sep  1  2024 setup.py
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit  3969 Nov 29 15:11 solveit_requirements_freeze.txt
-rw-r--r--  1 root    solveit    26 Nov 29 17:19 solveit_settings.json
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit 39273 Nov 29 14:51 uv.lock


I had a couple of existing notebooks and some stuff before 17.15 that are not relevant. For example, I‚Äôm not using uv or the .venv that I had set up previously. I did do a git initialize before running nbdev_new, though.

!ls -la nbs/

total 36
drwxrwsr-x  4 solveit solveit 4096 Nov 29 17:28 .
drwxrwsr-x 12 solveit solveit 4096 Nov 29 22:05 ..
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit  965 Sep  1  2024 00_core.ipynb
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit  330 Nov 29 17:15 _quarto.yml
drwxrwsr-x  2 solveit solveit 4096 Nov 29 17:28 dialogs
drwxrwsr-x  2 solveit solveit 4096 Nov 29 17:28 entries
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit 3896 Nov 29 17:15 index.ipynb
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit  246 Nov 29 17:15 nbdev.yml
-rw-rw-r--  1 solveit solveit  600 Sep  1  2024 styles.css


Should be out-of-the-box config here.



Yes, this is the standard nbdev setup:

index.ipynb - becomes your home page
00_core.ipynb - example module notebook
_quarto.yml - Quarto configuration for the site
nbdev.yml - nbdev settings
styles.css - custom styling

Now, for your journaling setup with date-based organization and dialog sections, we need to think about structure. A few options:

Flat structure with naming conventions (e.g., 2024-11-29_topic.ipynb, dialog_2024-11-29.ipynb)
Subdirectories (e.g., nbs/entries/, nbs/dialogs/)
Hybrid approach using both

We‚Äôll also need to configure _quarto.yml to organize the navigation how you want it.
Which approach appeals to you, or would you like to hear more about the trade-offs of each?
I‚Äôd like to use sub-dirs and also a naming convention. Dates for journal entries, and dialogs with topical file names.

nbs/entries/ - for date-based journal entries (e.g., 2024-11-29.ipynb); one per day
nbs/dialogs/ - for dialog-based entries with topical names (e.g., nbdev_setup.ipynb)
visible tags like this #tag: idea that can be a top-line tag for the entry or notebook, and also inline tag for cells.

The idea is that I‚Äôd like to be able to create a page that aggregate content with a particular tag on a page later.
I like #tag: idea. It‚Äôs familiar.



Perfect! #tag:idea is clear and familiar.
Now let‚Äôs create the directory structure. Would you like to create the entries/ and dialogs/ subdirectories yourself, or would you like me to show you the commands to do it?

!mkdir -p nbs/entries nbs/dialogs
!ls nbs/

00_core.ipynb  dialogs  index.ipynb  styles.css
_quarto.yml    entries  nbdev.yml






Great. Now what?


Excellent! The directories are created. Now we need to configure _quarto.yml to set up the navigation structure so your site will have separate sections for journal entries and dialogs.
Would you like to look at the current _quarto.yml file first to see what‚Äôs there? You can view it with:
!cat nbs/_quarto.yml

!cat nbs/_quarto.yml

project:
  type: website

format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
    css: styles.css
    toc: true
    keep-md: true
  commonmark: default

website:
  twitter-card: true
  open-graph: true
  repo-actions: [issue]
  navbar:
    background: primary
    search: true
  sidebar:
    style: floating

metadata-files: [nbdev.yml, sidebar.yml]


Let‚Äôs continue



Good! The current _quarto.yml is using sidebar.yml for navigation. We need to create that file to organize your entries and dialogs sections.
Here‚Äôs what the sidebar.yml structure could look like:
website:
  sidebar:
    contents:
      - index.ipynb
      - section: "Journal Entries"
        contents:
          - entries/*.ipynb
      - section: "Dialogs"
        contents:
          - dialogs/*.ipynb
Would you like to create this file, or would you prefer a different organization for the sidebar?
Let‚Äôs continue



To create the sidebar.yml file, you can use:
with open('nbs/sidebar.yml', 'w') as f:
    f.write(...)
Would you like to write this yourself, or would you like me to provide the complete code to create it?
give me a hand



Here you go:
sidebar_content = """website:
  sidebar:
    contents:
      - index.ipynb
      - section: "Journal Entries"
        contents:
          - entries/*.ipynb
      - section: "Dialogs"
        contents:
          - dialogs/*.ipynb
"""

with open('nbs/sidebar.yml', 'w') as f:
    f.write(sidebar_content)
This will create the sidebar structure with your two main sections. Try running it and let me know when you‚Äôre ready for the next step!

sidebar_content = """website:
  sidebar:
    contents:
      - index.ipynb
      - section: "Journal Entries"
        contents:
          - entries/*.ipynb
      - section: "Dialogs"
        contents:
          - dialogs/*.ipynb
"""

with open('nbs/sidebar.yml', 'w') as f:
    f.write(sidebar_content)

What else?



Now you could create your first journal entry or dialog notebook to test the structure. For a journal entry, you‚Äôd create something like nbs/entries/2024-11-29.ipynb, and for a dialog, maybe nbs/dialogs/nbdev_journaling.ipynb.
You could also add tags to your notebooks. In nbdev/Quarto, you can add metadata to the notebook or use special comment syntax in cells.
Which would you like to tackle first: 1. Create a sample notebook (entry or dialog)? 2. Set up the tagging system? 3. Something else you have in mind?




Let‚Äôs set up the tagging system and then use this notebook as a sample dialog.


Great idea! For the tagging system, there are a few approaches we could take:

Frontmatter tags - Add tags in the notebook‚Äôs YAML metadata at the top
Cell-level tags - Use Jupyter‚Äôs built-in cell tags feature
Custom comment syntax - Like your #tag: idea format in markdown or code cells
Combination - Use multiple approaches for flexibility

The frontmatter approach would look like:
---
title: "Nbdev Setup"
tags: [nbdev, journaling, setup]
---
Your #tag: idea syntax could work in markdown cells and be parsed later to aggregate content.
Which approach appeals to you most, or would you like to use a combination?
Let‚Äôs try each of these. How do I enter frontmatter tags in this notebook?



In a Jupyter notebook, you add frontmatter by creating a raw cell at the very top of the notebook with YAML content between --- markers.
Here‚Äôs how to do it:

Insert a new cell at the top of this notebook
Change the cell type to ‚ÄúRaw‚Äù (you can use the dropdown or press Esc then R)
Add content like:

---
title: "Nbdev Setup Dialog"
tags: [nbdev, journaling, setup, dialog]
date: 2024-11-29
---
Try adding that now. Can you create the raw cell with frontmatter?
Solveit notebooks don‚Äôt have cell-level tagging. How would I add custom metadata to cell JSON?



In solveit notebooks, each cell has a JSON structure. To add custom metadata, you‚Äôd need to edit the notebook file directly as JSON.
Each cell in the .ipynb file has a metadata field where you can add custom properties. For example:
{
  "cell_type": "markdown",
  "metadata": {
    "tags": ["idea", "important"]
  },
  "source": ["# My content"]
}
However, since solveit doesn‚Äôt have a UI for this, you‚Äôd need to either: 1. Edit the .ipynb file as JSON in a text editor 2. Write Python code to programmatically add metadata to cells
Would you like to explore writing a helper function to add tags to cells programmatically, or would you prefer to stick with the comment-based approach (#tag: idea) that‚Äôs easier to use while working?
For now let‚Äôs use the custom syntax (#tag: idea). But help me understand how I can programmatically add metadata to cells via a helper function.



Good choice on the custom syntax for now! For programmatic metadata editing, here‚Äôs the concept:
A Jupyter notebook is just a JSON file. You can load it with Python‚Äôs json module or use nbformat, which is designed for this. The basic structure is:
import nbformat

# Load notebook
nb = nbformat.read('path/to/notebook.ipynb', as_version=4)

# Each cell is in nb.cells, and has a .metadata dict
for cell in nb.cells:
    if 'tags' not in cell.metadata:
        cell.metadata['tags'] = []
    cell.metadata['tags'].append('my-tag')

# Save it back
nbformat.write(nb, 'path/to/notebook.ipynb')
The cell.metadata is just a Python dict, so you can add any keys you want. The tags key is standard Jupyter convention.
Does this make sense? Would you like to try creating a simple helper function to add tags to a notebook?
Yes. I‚Äôd like a function that I can add to the any cell that calls the helper and passes a tag or list of tags.



Great idea! Here‚Äôs the approach:
You‚Äôd create a function like:
def tag_cell(tags):
    # Get the current notebook and cell
    # Add tags to that cell's metadata
    pass
The tricky part is identifying which cell is calling the function. In Jupyter/IPython, you can use get_ipython() to access the kernel, but finding the exact cell that‚Äôs executing requires some inspection of the execution history.
Would you like to: 1. Create a function that tags cells by their execution order (simpler) 2. Try to identify the calling cell more precisely (trickier) 3. Use a different approach, like a function that takes a cell index as a parameter?
Which sounds most useful for your workflow?
How do we get a cell index? Can we do that from within the cell?



Getting the cell index from within a running cell is challenging because when Python code executes, it doesn‚Äôt inherently know which cell it came from.
However, there are a few possibilities:

IPython execution count - Each cell has an In[n] number you can access with get_ipython().execution_count, but this is execution order, not cell position
Inspect the notebook file - Read the .ipynb file and match cell content or execution count to find position
Manual passing - You explicitly pass an identifier when calling the function

The most reliable approach would be to read the current notebook file and use execution count or cell content to find the cell‚Äôs position.
Would you like to explore option 2 (inspecting the notebook file)? We‚Äôd need to know the current notebook‚Äôs filename first.
Pause for now. Let‚Äôs move to previewing this site. This is what I believe must happen. Please make improvements or aid with helpful comments.

nbdev_clean
nbdev_export
nbdev_docs (updates the readme) ‚Äì not sure if necessary
git add -A
Git commit
Git push - we‚Äôll need to set up a remote with GitHub
Turn on gh-pages to gh-pages branch on root
GitHub actions will automatically do things like run nbdev_tests and quarto ghp




Good plan! A few clarifications and additions:
Your sequence is mostly right:

nbdev_export - Exports code from notebooks to Python modules (needed if you have code to export)
nbdev_docs - Builds the Quarto site locally in _docs/
git add -A and commit
git push - Yes, you‚Äôll need to set up the GitHub remote first
GitHub Actions will handle nbdev_test and deploy via quarto publish gh-pages

Notes: - nbdev_clean removes notebook outputs - useful but optional here - nbdev_docs is mainly for local preview; GitHub Actions will rebuild the site - You don‚Äôt manually configure gh-pages branch - the GitHub Action (nbdev_ci.yaml) handles deployment automatically
Want to preview locally first? Run nbdev_preview instead - it builds and serves the site so you can view it at localhost:3000.
Would you like to: 1. Preview locally first with nbdev_preview? 2. Set up the GitHub remote and push?





# !curl http://localhost:8000

I‚Äôm unable to see this site from the browser using the vm url at port 8000. From my understanding, this is the port that fastHTML apps are served via JupyUvi in solveit. This leads me to believe that this is the intended (open) port. Thoughts?


You‚Äôre right that port 8000 is what‚Äôs exposed in solveit for FastHTML apps. However, nbdev_preview uses Quarto‚Äôs preview server, which typically runs on port 3000 or another port by default.
Options to fix this:

Tell Quarto to use port 8000:
!quarto preview nbs --port 8000 --host 0.0.0.0
Check what port nbdev_preview is actually using - look at the output when you ran it

Did you run nbdev_preview already? If so, what output did it show about the port/URL?
Seems like port 8000 is what we use on solveit‚Äôs platform. That didn‚Äôt work. So for now‚Ä¶ no preview from my solveit vm.




Note - the challenge with installing nbdev at the top-level of this VM is that I had to be very careful with the .gitignore because of sensitive files and dirs. I would create a separate dir in the future. Here‚Äôs my .gitignore.

title: Nbdev Setup Dialog
text:
I‚Äôd like to set up an instance of nbdev as a journaling framework in solveit where I can journal about knowledge that I‚Äôve gained through dialog engineering or via a synthesis of reading, thinking, and coding. I would like a date-based organization for primary navigational structure, but also want separate section of dialogues that I incorporate from solveit within this journal. I‚Äôd also like to make use of tags both in code cells and documentation. For example, I‚Äôd like to be able to tag someone else‚Äôs dialog that I‚Äôd like to re-visit, tag ideas, and tag fragments of knowledge that seem useful.
nbdev and quarto are installed in solveit per investigation in this dialog https://sparkling-sunset-rushes-5idg2w.solve.it.com/dialog_?name=nbdev_environment. I‚Äôm using this same instance to set up nvdev and know that I can initialize via nbdev_new. Is this a good place to start?


Yes, nbdev_new is a good starting point! It will create the basic structure for an nbdev project. However, before we run it, let‚Äôs think about a few things to customize it for your journaling needs:

Project name: What would you like to call your journal project? (e.g., ‚Äúknowledge-journal‚Äù, ‚Äúdialog-journal‚Äù, etc.)
Structure considerations: The default nbdev setup is designed for Python libraries, but we can adapt it. You mentioned wanting:

Date-based organization for primary navigation
A separate section for dialog entries
Tag support throughout


After we initialize with nbdev_new, we‚Äôll need to customize the structure and settings to support these features.
Should we start by running nbdev_new with a project name you choose, and then we can explore how to adapt the structure for your journaling workflow?
Given nb_dev is interactive, can I install from within this notebook? Will I be able to respond properly to input?



Good question! Yes, you can run nbdev_new from within a code cell in solveit, but there‚Äôs a catch with the interactive prompts.
nbdev_new will ask you questions interactively (like project name, author, etc.), and while it will technically work in a notebook cell, responding to the prompts can be tricky in this environment.
You have a couple of options:

Use command-line flags to pass all the info at once (non-interactive mode)
Try the interactive mode and see if it works smoothly in solveit

Would you like to try option 1 (providing all parameters upfront), or would you prefer to experiment with the interactive mode first to see how it behaves?
If I try the interactive mode and something goes wrong‚Ä¶ can we back out and go to the first option?



Absolutely! If the interactive mode doesn‚Äôt work well, you can just interrupt it (or let it fail), and we can switch to using the command-line flags instead. Nothing will break permanently.
The worst case is that it creates a partially configured project, which we can either delete or just run nbdev_new again with flags to overwrite it.
So yes, it‚Äôs safe to experiment. Would you like to try the interactive mode first?
I‚Äôve run set up - how shall we proceed?



Great! Now let‚Äôs see what nbdev_new created for you. Could you run:
!ls -la
This will show us the directory structure that was set up. Once we see what‚Äôs there, we can discuss how to adapt it for your journaling needs (date-based organization, dialog sections, and tagging).
What does the output show?

!ls -la

total 192
drwxrwsr-x 12 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 22:05 .
drwxr-xr-x  1 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 14:25 ..
-rw-------  1 solveit solveit   394 Nov 29 17:34 .bash_history
drwxrwsr-x  8 solveit solveit  4096 Nov 29 17:15 .cache

I had a couple of existing notebooks and some stuff before 17.15 that are not relevant. For example, I‚Äôm not using uv or the .venv that I had set up previously. I did do a git initialize before running nbdev_new, though.

Should be out-of-the-box config here.

00_core.ipynb - example module notebook

Subdirectories (e.g., nbs/entries/, nbs/dialogs/)
Hybrid approach using both

We‚Äôll also need to configure _quarto.yml to organize the navigation how you want it.
Which approach appeals to you, or would you like to hear more about the trade-offs of each?
I‚Äôd like to use sub-dirs and also a naming convention. Dates for journal entries, and dialogs with topical file names.

nbs/entries/ - for date-based journal entries (e.g., 2024-11-29.ipynb); one per day
nbs/dialogs/ - for dialog-based entries with topical names (e.g., nbdev_setup.ipynb)
visible tags like this #tag: idea that can be a top-line tag for the entry or notebook, and also inline tag for cells.

The idea is that I‚Äôd like to be able to create a page that aggregate content with a particular tag on a page later.
I like #tag: idea. It‚Äôs familiar.



Perfect! #tag:idea is clear and familiar.
Now let‚Äôs create the directory structure. Would you like to create the entries/ and dialogs/ subdirectories yourself, or would you like me to show you the commands to do it?

!mkdir -p nbs/entries nbs/dialogs
!ls nbs/

00_core.ipynb  dialogs  index.ipynb  styles.css
_quarto.yml    entries  nbdev.yml

title: Nbdev Setup Dialog
text:
Great. Now what?


Excellent! The directories are created. Now we need to configure _quarto.yml to set up the navigation structure so your site will have separate sections for journal entries and dialogs.
Would you like to look at the current _quarto.yml file first to see what‚Äôs there? You can view it with:
!cat nbs/_quarto.yml

!cat nbs/_quarto.yml

project:
  type: website

format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
    css: styles.css
    toc: true
    keep-md: true
  commonmark: default

website:
  twitter-card: true
  open-graph: true
  repo-actions: [issue]
  navbar:
    background: primary
    search: true
  sidebar:
    style: floating

metadata-files: [nbdev.yml, sidebar.yml]


Let‚Äôs continue



Good! The current _quarto.yml is using sidebar.yml for navigation. We need to create that file to organize your entries and dialogs sections.
Here‚Äôs what the sidebar.yml structure could look like:
website:
  sidebar:
    contents:
      - index.ipynb
      - section: "Journal Entries"
        contents:
          - entries/*.ipynb
      - section: "Dialogs"
        contents:
          - dialogs/*.ipynb
Would you like to create this file, or would you prefer a different organization for the sidebar?
Let‚Äôs continue



To create the sidebar.yml file, you can use:
with open('nbs/sidebar.yml', 'w') as f:
    f.write(...)
Would you like to write this yourself, or would you like me to provide the complete code to create it?
give me a hand



Here you go:
sidebar_content = """website:
  sidebar:
    contents:
      - index.ipynb
      - section: "Journal Entries"
        contents:
          - entries/*.ipynb
      - section: "Dialogs"
        contents:
          - dialogs/*.ipynb
"""

with open('nbs/sidebar.yml', 'w') as f:
    f.write(sidebar_content)
This will create the sidebar structure with your two main sections. Try running it and let me know when you‚Äôre ready for the next step!

sidebar_content = """website:
  sidebar:
    contents:
      - index.ipynb
      - section: "Journal Entries"
        contents:
          - entries/*.ipynb
      - section: "Dialogs"
        contents:
          - dialogs/*.ipynb
"""

with open('nbs/sidebar.yml', 'w') as f:
    f.write(sidebar_content)

What else?



Now you could create your first journal entry or dialog notebook to test the structure. For a journal entry, you‚Äôd create something like nbs/entries/2024-11-29.ipynb, and for a dialog, maybe nbs/dialogs/nbdev_journaling.ipynb.
You could also add tags to your notebooks. In nbdev/Quarto, you can add metadata to the notebook or use special comment syntax in cells.
Which would you like to tackle first: 1. Create a sample notebook (entry or dialog)? 2. Set up the tagging system? 3. Something else you have in mind?

title: Nbdev Setup Dialog
text:
Let‚Äôs set up the tagging system and then use this notebook as a sample dialog.


Great idea! For the tagging system, there are a few approaches we could take:

Frontmatter tags - Add tags in the notebook‚Äôs YAML metadata at the top
Cell-level tags - Use Jupyter‚Äôs built-in cell tags feature
Custom comment syntax - Like your #tag: idea format in markdown or code cells
Combination - Use multiple approaches for flexibility

The frontmatter approach would look like:
---
title: "Nbdev Setup"
tags: [nbdev, journaling, setup]
---
Your #tag: idea syntax could work in markdown cells and be parsed later to aggregate content.
Which approach appeals to you most, or would you like to use a combination?
Let‚Äôs try each of these. How do I enter frontmatter tags in this notebook?



In a Jupyter notebook, you add frontmatter by creating a raw cell at the very top of the notebook with YAML content between --- markers.
Here‚Äôs how to do it:

Insert a new cell at the top of this notebook
Change the cell type to ‚ÄúRaw‚Äù (you can use the dropdown or press Esc then R)
Add content like:

---
title: "Nbdev Setup Dialog"
tags: [nbdev, journaling, setup, dialog]
date: 2024-11-29
---
Try adding that now. Can you create the raw cell with frontmatter?
Solveit notebooks don‚Äôt have cell-level tagging. How would I add custom metadata to cell JSON?



In solveit notebooks, each cell has a JSON structure. To add custom metadata, you‚Äôd need to edit the notebook file directly as JSON.
Each cell in the .ipynb file has a metadata field where you can add custom properties. For example:
{
  "cell_type": "markdown",
  "metadata": {
    "tags": ["idea", "important"]
  },
  "source": ["# My content"]
}
However, since solveit doesn‚Äôt have a UI for this, you‚Äôd need to either: 1. Edit the .ipynb file as JSON in a text editor 2. Write Python code to programmatically add metadata to cells
Would you like to explore writing a helper function to add tags to cells programmatically, or would you prefer to stick with the comment-based approach (#tag: idea) that‚Äôs easier to use while working?
For now let‚Äôs use the custom syntax (#tag: idea). But help me understand how I can programmatically add metadata to cells via a helper function.



Good choice on the custom syntax for now! For programmatic metadata editing, here‚Äôs the concept:
A Jupyter notebook is just a JSON file. You can load it with Python‚Äôs json module or use nbformat, which is designed for this. The basic structure is:
import nbformat

# Load notebook
nb = nbformat.read('path/to/notebook.ipynb', as_version=4)

# Each cell is in nb.cells, and has a .metadata dict
for cell in nb.cells:
    if 'tags' not in cell.metadata:
        cell.metadata['tags'] = []
    cell.metadata['tags'].append('my-tag')

# Save it back
nbformat.write(nb, 'path/to/notebook.ipynb')
The cell.metadata is just a Python dict, so you can add any keys you want. The tags key is standard Jupyter convention.
Does this make sense? Would you like to try creating a simple helper function to add tags to a notebook?
Yes. I‚Äôd like a function that I can add to the any cell that calls the helper and passes a tag or list of tags.



Great idea! Here‚Äôs the approach:
You‚Äôd create a function like:
def tag_cell(tags):
    # Get the current notebook and cell
    # Add tags to that cell's metadata
    pass
The tricky part is identifying which cell is calling the function. In Jupyter/IPython, you can use get_ipython() to access the kernel, but finding the exact cell that‚Äôs executing requires some inspection of the execution history.
Would you like to: 1. Create a function that tags cells by their execution order (simpler) 2. Try to identify the calling cell more precisely (trickier) 3. Use a different approach, like a function that takes a cell index as a parameter?
Which sounds most useful for your workflow?
How do we get a cell index? Can we do that from within the cell?



Getting the cell index from within a running cell is challenging because when Python code executes, it doesn‚Äôt inherently know which cell it came from.
However, there are a few possibilities:

IPython execution count - Each cell has an In[n] number you can access with get_ipython().execution_count, but this is execution order, not cell position
Inspect the notebook file - Read the .ipynb file and match cell content or execution count to find position
Manual passing - You explicitly pass an identifier when calling the function

The most reliable approach would be to read the current notebook file and use execution count or cell content to find the cell‚Äôs position.
Would you like to explore option 2 (inspecting the notebook file)? We‚Äôd need to know the current notebook‚Äôs filename first.
Pause for now. Let‚Äôs move to previewing this site. This is what I believe must happen. Please make improvements or aid with helpful comments.

nbdev_clean
nbdev_export
nbdev_docs (updates the readme) ‚Äì not sure if necessary
git add -A
Git commit
Git push - we‚Äôll need to set up a remote with GitHub
Turn on gh-pages to gh-pages branch on root
GitHub actions will automatically do things like run nbdev_tests and quarto ghp




Good plan! A few clarifications and additions:
Your sequence is mostly right:

nbdev_export - Exports code from notebooks to Python modules (needed if you have code to export)
nbdev_docs - Builds the Quarto site locally in _docs/
git add -A and commit
git push - Yes, you‚Äôll need to set up the GitHub remote first
GitHub Actions will handle nbdev_test and deploy via quarto publish gh-pages

Notes: - nbdev_clean removes notebook outputs - useful but optional here - nbdev_docs is mainly for local preview; GitHub Actions will rebuild the site - You don‚Äôt manually configure gh-pages branch - the GitHub Action (nbdev_ci.yaml) handles deployment automatically
Want to preview locally first? Run nbdev_preview instead - it builds and serves the site so you can view it at localhost:3000.
Would you like to: 1. Preview locally first with nbdev_preview? 2. Set up the GitHub remote and push?

title: Nbdev Setup Dialog
text:
# !curl http://localhost:8000

I‚Äôm unable to see this site from the browser using the vm url at port 8000. From my understanding, this is the port that fastHTML apps are served via JupyUvi in solveit. This leads me to believe that this is the intended (open) port. Thoughts?


You‚Äôre right that port 8000 is what‚Äôs exposed in solveit for FastHTML apps. However, nbdev_preview uses Quarto‚Äôs preview server, which typically runs on port 3000 or another port by default.
Options to fix this:

Tell Quarto to use port 8000:
!quarto preview nbs --port 8000 --host 0.0.0.0
Check what port nbdev_preview is actually using - look at the output when you ran it

Did you run nbdev_preview already? If so, what output did it show about the port/URL?
Seems like port 8000 is what we use on solveit‚Äôs platform. That didn‚Äôt work. So for now‚Ä¶ no preview from my solveit vm.

title: Nbdev Setup Dialog
text: Note - the challenge with installing nbdev at the top-level of this VM is that I had to be very careful with the .gitignore because of sensitive files and dirs. I would create a separate dir in the future. Here‚Äôs my .gitignore.

title: Nbdev Setup Dialog
section: Pull from GitHub and run on local computer
text:
Pull from GitHub and run on local computer
This was straightforward. On my local machine, I had to make a small change in solveit_requirements_freeze.txt, so I created a requirements_mac.txt that eliminated the solveit library and the +cpu options on torch libs.
Is there advice for working between computers when I can only do an nbdev_preview on the local machine? I believe that if I move my solveit nbs to the dialog dir here - and handle custom libs, accordingly, there shouldn‚Äôt be any real issues.

ü§ñReplyü§ñ
Good question! Here‚Äôs a workflow that should work well for your situation:
Development flow: 1. Work on content in solveit (where you have full dialog engineering capabilities) 2. Push changes to GitHub from solveit 3. Pull to local machine for preview with nbdev_preview 4. Make any preview-related tweaks locally if needed 5. Push back to GitHub
Key considerations: - Keep your notebooks in nbs/entries/ or nbs/dialogs/ regardless of where you create them - Custom libs: If you use solveit-specific libraries in your notebooks, you have a few options: - Add conditional imports (check if lib exists before importing) - Keep those notebooks as documentation-only (no code execution needed for preview) - Mock the imports in your local environment
Does this match what you were thinking? Or do you have specific solveit libraries you‚Äôre concerned about handling?

title: Goal
text:
My goal is to install and use nbdev as a journal here in solveit and sync using github in a local version on my laptop. I would like parity across the two environments.
import sys, sysconfig, platform, pip, jupyter_client

title: Goal
text:
Get basic info
We want to get the exact specs for: - Python version - Site packages - Quarto
We know that the terminal env is not the same as Solveit‚Äôs jupyter env which is containerized. We‚Äôd also like to know something about the jupyter kernel and environment.
It looks like this environment does not run conda (yay!), though by poking and prodding it also does not use uv, which I prefer in my local envs.

print("Python exec:", sys.executable)
print("Python version:", platform.python_version())
print("Site-packages:", sysconfig.get_paths()["purelib"])
pip.__version__

Python exec: /usr/local/bin/python
Python version: 3.12.12
Site-packages: /usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages


'25.3'



sys.executable??




Give me a brief summary of this library and the utility of this property.

ü§ñReplyü§ñ
sys.executable is a property from Python‚Äôs sys module that returns the absolute path to the Python interpreter currently running your code.
In your case, it shows /usr/local/bin/python, which tells you exactly which Python executable is being used by your Jupyter kernel in this solveit environment.
Why is this useful for your goal?
Since you want parity between your solveit environment and your local laptop setup, knowing the exact Python interpreter path helps you: - Verify which Python installation is active (important when multiple versions exist) - Understand the environment structure for package installations - Ensure your local setup mirrors the solveit configuration
This is especially relevant since you noted that solveit doesn‚Äôt use conda or uv - sys.executable confirms you‚Äôre working with a standard Python installation.
Would you like to gather more environment information to compare with your local setup?
What is the platform library?


ü§ñReplyü§ñ
The platform library is a Python standard library module that provides information about the underlying system and platform where Python is running.
It can tell you things like: - Operating system (Linux, Windows, macOS) - OS version - Machine architecture (x86_64, ARM, etc.) - Python implementation details
For example, platform.system() returns the OS name, and platform.machine() tells you the processor architecture.
Would you like to explore what information it reveals about your solveit environment?
Why do we need both libraries? They seem to overlap.


ü§ñReplyü§ñ
Good observation! They do overlap, but they serve different purposes:
sys focuses on the Python interpreter itself: - The Python executable path - Command-line arguments - Module paths and imports - Runtime behavior
platform focuses on the underlying system: - Operating system details - Hardware architecture - Python implementation (CPython, PyPy, etc.)
For your nbdev setup goal, sys is more useful for understanding the Python environment, while platform helps with system compatibility checks.
You could often get by with just one, depending on what you need. For matching environments across solveit and your laptop, sys is probably more directly useful.
Does that distinction make sense?

sysconfig.get_paths()

{'stdlib': '/usr/local/lib/python3.12',

os.environ.get("CONDA_DEFAULT_ENV"), os.environ.get("VIRTUAL_ENV")

(None, None)


Get exact package requirements to make this portable for my local env.

import importlib.metadata as md

reqs = []
for d in md.distributions():
    name = d.metadata['Name']
    try:
        version = md.version(name)
        reqs.append(f"{name}=={version}")
    except:
        pass

print("\n".join(sorted(reqs)))
with open("solveit_requirements_freeze.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("\n".join(sorted(reqs)))

What is the diff between purelib and platlib?


ü§ñReplyü§ñ
Good question! Both are site-packages locations, but for different types of packages:
purelib (pure library): Python-only code with no compiled extensions. Works on any platform.
platlib (platform library): Contains platform-specific compiled code (like C extensions). Think numpy, pandas‚Äîpackages with binary components that differ between Windows/Linux/Mac.
In your solveit environment, they both point to the same location (/usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages), which is common in many Python installations. The distinction matters more when you have separate directories for pure vs platform-specific code.
Does this affect your thinking about syncing between solveit and your local environment?

title: Goal
section: Check for changes periodically, and capture
text:
Check for changes periodically, and capture
Later when things drift, get a diff:
diff solveit_requirements_freeze.txt solveit_requirements_freeze_new.txt
To summarize so far, this is what Solveit is using:
Python exec: /usr/local/bin/python
Site-packages: /usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages

My site-packages list (frozen in solveit_requirements_freeze.txt) are in the top level app/data dir of this instance.

title: Goal
text:
Update Local env
I use uv and .venv in my local envirnments.
Do this in the local env:
python3.12 -m venv solveit-mirror
source solveit-mirror/bin/activate
pip install -r solveit_requirements_freeze_new.txt

Am I missing something here, and how can I make sure the versions (e.g., Python, Quarto, site-packages) remain in sync when changes are made on the Solveit platform?

ü§ñReplyü§ñ
üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†
Great goal! You‚Äôve done solid detective work capturing the environment specs. A few clarifying questions before we dig in:

Python version parity: Solveit is running Python 3.12.12. What version do you have locally, and are you flexible about matching it exactly?
Quarto: You noted Quarto 1.8.24 here. Do you have Quarto installed locally already?
Sync direction: When Solveit‚Äôs environment updates (new package versions, etc.), do you want to primarily pull those changes to your local env, or do you anticipate needing changes to flow both ways?

Also, one thing I noticed: you‚Äôre creating a local venv from the frozen requirements, which is a good approach. But the Solveit environment itself doesn‚Äôt appear to use a venv or conda‚Äîit‚Äôs a containerized system-level Python. This means you won‚Äôt have identical environments, but you can get functionally equivalent ones for nbdev workflows.
What‚Äôs your current local setup look like?

title: Goal
section: Side path - decided against using uv in solveit
text:
Side path - decided against using uv in solveit

# !python -m pip install uv

I thought I might try to create the pyproject.toml using uv‚Ä¶ but decided it wasn‚Äôt necessary.

import sys
print(sys.executable)
!{sys.executable} -m pip show uv

/usr/local/bin/python
Name: uv
Version: 0.9.13
Summary: An extremely fast Python package and project manager, written in Rust.

title: Goal
section: Partly automating the check for parity between envs
text:
Partly automating the check for parity between envs
I use uv locally and can ensure Python and Quarto parity so long as I know about changes. I only want to sync from Solveit to local.

ü§ñReplyü§ñ
üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†
Perfect, that simplifies things. Since you‚Äôre pulling one-way from Solveit ‚Üí local, here‚Äôs the key question:
How do you want to detect changes?
A few options:

Manual periodic check: Re-run your freeze script occasionally and diff against your saved solveit_requirements_freeze.txt
Session-start check: Add a small snippet at the top of your journal that prints versions of key packages (nbdev, fastcore, quarto) so you notice drift quickly
Hash-based detection: Generate a hash of the installed packages and compare to a stored value‚Äîquick way to know ‚Äúsomething changed‚Äù without seeing what

Which approach appeals to you? Or would you like a combination?
Also, for the nbdev journal itself: have you already run nbdev_new or set up a repo structure, or are you starting fresh?
I like the session-start check, if you can help with that. I am starting fresh with nbdev in solveit.


ü§ñReplyü§ñ
Great! Let‚Äôs create a simple session-start check. Here‚Äôs a small snippet that will show you the versions of key packages:
import sys
import importlib.metadata as md

packages = ['nbdev', 'fastcore', 'quarto']
print(f"Python: {sys.version.split()[0]}")
for pkg in packages:
    try:
        print(f"{pkg}: {md.version(pkg)}")
    except:
        print(f"{pkg}: not installed")
You can run this at the start of each session to quickly spot changes. Want to try it?
For starting fresh with nbdev: have you thought about what you‚Äôd like to name your journal project, or should we just use something simple like ‚Äúsolveit-journal‚Äù?

import sys
import importlib.metadata as md

packages = ['nbdev', 'fastcore', 'quarto']
print(f"Python: {sys.version.split()[0]}")
for pkg in packages:
    try:
        print(f"{pkg}: {md.version(pkg)}")
    except:
        print(f"{pkg}: not installed")

Python: 3.12.12
nbdev: 2.4.6
fastcore: 1.8.16
quarto: not installed


Is there an issue with the use of hyphens in nbdev project names? I believe there used to be.


ü§ñReplyü§ñ
Good catch! Yes, there can be issues with hyphens in nbdev project names because:

Python package names: While PyPI allows hyphens, Python imports require underscores (you can‚Äôt import my-package, only import my_package)
nbdev convention: nbdev typically converts hyphens to underscores for the actual package/module name, but this can create confusion between the repo name and import name

The safest approach is to use underscores throughout (like solveit_journal) or no separators at all (like solveitjournal).
What naming style do you prefer for your journal project?
I did a lot of tinkering in this notebook. Are there imports I can now delete by looking at the code cells in this notebook and cross-checking with my import statement?


ü§ñReplyü§ñ
üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†
Based on the code cells I can see, here‚Äôs what appears to be used vs unused from your main import:
import sys, sysconfig, platform, pkgutil, pip, json, pathlib, jupyter_client
Used: - sys ‚úì - sysconfig ‚úì - platform ‚úì - pip ‚úì - jupyter_client ‚úì
Appear unused: - pkgutil - json - pathlib
However, I can only see the cells that have been shared with me in this conversation. Are there other code cells in your notebook that might use these three?

title: Goal
text:
Reflection
How would you characterize the difference between the terminal environment in solveit vs solveit notebook env? What does this tell you about this virtual machine and what I must do to understand the python env in the notebook, versus use of libraries in my home directory?

ü§ñReplyü§ñ
üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†üß†
Good question! Based on what we‚Äôve discovered:
Notebook environment: - Uses /usr/local/bin/python (system-level, containerized) - Site-packages at /usr/local/lib/python3.12/site-packages - No venv or conda active
User installs (like your uv): - Go to /app/data/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages - Binaries land in /app/data/.local/bin/
Key insight: The container has a read-only system Python with pre-installed packages, but your /app/data/ directory is writable and persistent. User-installed packages go there.
This means:

To check what the notebook can import, always use sys.executable and importlib.metadata from within the notebook‚Äînot terminal commands
User-installed packages may need explicit PATH additions for binaries (like you did with /app/data/.local/bin/uv)
The system packages are managed by the Solveit platform; you can add packages but probably can‚Äôt upgrade the core ones

Does this match your mental model? And does it raise any concerns for your nbdev workflow?
Where should I put libraries that I write, that I might want to reference from a solveit notebook?


ü§ñReplyü§ñ
Great question! You have a few options depending on how you want to use your libraries:
Option 1: Install as editable package Put your library code in /app/data/ (or subdirectory), add a setup.py or pyproject.toml, then pip install -e . from that directory. This makes it importable from any notebook.
Option 2: Add to sys.path Put your library in /app/data/mylibs/ and add this to your notebook:
import sys
sys.path.insert(0, '/app/data/mylibs')
Option 3: Use nbdev Since you‚Äôre setting up nbdev, you could develop your library as an nbdev project in /app/data/, which gives you the editable install automatically.
Which approach sounds most aligned with your workflow? Are you planning to develop multiple separate libraries, or is this mainly for your journal/notebook utilities?
Just to be clear, if I decide to install a site-package that is not in the container, I can use the terminal and the package will be installed in /app/data/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages?


ü§ñReplyü§ñ
Yes, exactly! When you pip install from the terminal (or notebook with !pip install), packages will go to /app/data/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages since that‚Äôs your user site-packages directory.
You can verify this is already happening‚Äîremember when you installed uv earlier? It went to /app/data/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages.
The notebook‚Äôs Python will automatically find packages there because that directory is in its search path.
Want to test this with a small package to confirm it works as expected?
What have I learned.

I believe I can run this journal from both environments, while using Solveit as the primary environment.
I tinkered with sys, platform, sysconfig, jupyter_client, importlib_metadata modules and browsed source code. though can‚Äôt say I‚Äôm very familiar with any of them.
I learned that I can poke and prod at this containerized environment and also capture that information for use externally ‚Äì or trigger for critical updates in my notebooks.
I like the idea of keeping two envs in sync for my journal project, because there are times when thinking and editing locally is more efficient. For example, my kernel will not die unexpectedly, or my internet access will not pose an issue.
